There is consensus among the Government, the Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB),  and  the  aid  community  on  the  urgent  need  to  support 
the  development  of  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs)  to 
sustain economic growth and to progressively reduce the incidence 
of  poverty  in  Viet  Nam.  The  traditional  approach  to  assisting  SME 
development,  which  aimed  to  fill  SMEs'  funding  and  technical  gaps 
through  provision  of  subsidized  credit  or  services,  has achieved 
limited  results,  and  is  often  considered  unsustainable.  Increasingly, 
therefore,  SME  support  programs  are  shifting  to  creation  of  an 
enabling business environment. 
 
The SDPL Cluster is ADB’s first policy loan in Viet Nam specifically 
designed to foster an enabling environment for the SME sector as a 
key means for poverty reduction. Building from the achievements of 
Subprogram  I,  Subprogram  II  adopts  a  process-oriented  approach 
and  is  designed  to  systematically  identify  and  resolve  issues  and

Risks and Assumptions  There are four principal risks in implementing the SDPL-Subprogram 
II. The first involves effective coordination and cooperation within the 
government,  both  horizontally  among  ministries  and  agencies 
concerned,  and  vertically  with  the  provincial  and  district  authorities. 
Consultation  and  coordination  with  the  private  sector  and  the  aid 
community  active  in  SME  development  will  also  be  required.  It  is 
expected that coordination and cooperation among all stakeholders 
will gradually improve with the increased coordination capacity of the 
Agency  for  SME  Development  (ASMED),  thus  reducing  the  risk  of 
overlap  and  inconsistencies  in  SME  support  activities.  Technical 
assistance  grants  (TA)  in  support  of  the  SDPL  implementation  will 
include  capacity  building  for  ASMED  to  reduce  this  risk.  Overall, 
while  coordination  among  government  agencies  significantly 
improved  during  the  Subprogram  I  implementation,  it  remains an 
important issue.  
 
A second risk pertains to good governance of the central, provincial, 
and  district  governments.  Governance  at  the  provincial  and  district 
levels is particularly important since the positive impact of the SDPL 
will  be  felt  only  through  effective  implementation  of  policies  at  the 
ground level. These risks are common to several programs and are 
being  addressed  through  the  implementation  of  the  comprehensive 
Public Administration Reform Master Program for 2001–2010, which 
is being supported by ADB.

MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

5. 
Viet Nam's annual economic growth rate accelerated to an estimated 8.1% in 2005, up 
from  7.5%  in  2004,  and  7.1%  in  2003.  The  healthy  performance  was  achieved  despite  the 
adverse  impact  of  avian  influenza,  drought  for  part  of  the  year,  a  more  challenging  export

contributor to growth; exports also remained strong. Gross fixed investment continued to grow, 
reflecting  improvements  in  the  business  environment.  Investments  accounted  for  37.6%  of 
gross domestic product (GDP) in 2005, up from 29% in 1998.

c. 

Improved Legal Environment for Financial Leasing Companies 

49. 
Financial leasing operations in Viet Nam are governed by Decree 16 (May 2001), which 
was later amended by  Decree 65 (June 2005) and Circular No. 8/2001/TT-NHNN (September 
2001) issued by the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV). The activities of financial leasing companies 
(FLCs)  are  confined  to  (i)  financial  leasing  for  machinery,  equipment,  vehicles,  and  other 
movable assets; (ii) advising clients on matters relating to financial leasing operations; and (ii) 
other  services  related  to  financial  leasing.  Decree  65  permits  sale  and  leaseback  transactions 
and syndicated leasing, but implementing regulations have to be issued. Transactions in foreign 
currency are subject to the foreign exchange control regulations of SBV. FLCs are permitted to 
mobilize capital from (i) short-, medium-, and long-term borrowing from credit institutions in Viet 
Nam  and  abroad;  (ii)  issuance  of  bonds  with  a  term  of  more  than  1  year  (subject  to  SBV 
approval); and (iii) other means as stipulated in Article 16 of Decree 16. 
 
50. 
The  development  of  the  leasing  industry  in  Viet  Nam  is  particularly  constrained  by 
shortcomings in the legal framework that restrict both the activities and the funding mechanisms 
of FLCs. The Government recognizes that the absence of implementing regulations for sale and 
leaseback  transactions  and  syndicated  leasing  constrains  FLCs  from  offering  a  fuller  product 
range  tailored  to  market  needs.  Long-term  funding  also  presents  a  problem  for  some  FLCs, 
including subsidiaries of state-owned commercial banks (SOCBs) that source all or most of their 
funds from their respective parent banks. Thus, in general, there is a mismatch in financing in 
FLCs  between  their  borrowing  (short-term)  and  lending  (long-term,  as  leasing  transactions). 
Leasing companies have cited difficulties in attracting term loans of more than 1 year at viable 
interest rates, and relatively few have been successful in issuing medium- or long-term bonds.  
 
51. 
To address these constraints, Subprogram I (per Conditions 2-8 and 2-9) has supported 
the  SBV  in  the  issuance  of  implementing  guidelines  for  Decree  65,  to  specify  policies  and 
procedures  for  (i)  sale  of  lease  receivables,  (ii)  sale  and  leaseback  transactions,  and  (iii) 
syndicated leasing.  A pilot program was launched in March 2006 with the following participating 
institutions: (i) Viet Nam Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development, (ii) Viet Nam International 
Leasing Company, (iii) Asia Commercial Bank, and (iv) Bank for Industrial Development of Viet 
Nam.  Under  the  pilot,  provisional  guidelines26  have  been  developed  by  the  SBV  to  allow  the 
participating  institutions  to  sell  lease  receivables.  As  of  mid-June  2006,  total  transactions

53.  Many SME surveys in Viet Nam point to limited access to land as the foremost constraint 
to  their  growth.27  Issues  on  SMEs’  access  to  land  revolve  around  inefficiencies  resulting  from 
inconsistencies and biases distinct to economies in transition. For example, there is a significant 
difference in the proportion of land use rights held by SOEs compared with those held by private 
sector  SMEs.  The  economic  transformation  process  has  resulted  in  a  large  amount  of  prime 
commercial  and  industrial  land  being  allocated  to  SOEs.  However,  many  do  not  take  full 
advantage  of  the  land  allocated  to  them  in  their  industrial  or  commercial  activities.  Much  land 
allocated to SOEs is left idle with no plans for future use, while the rapidly growing private SMEs 
are  suffering  from  lack  of  land.  Consequently,  leasing  idle  land  from  SOEs  has  become  the 
most  common  method  used  by  private  sector  SMEs  to  obtain  land,  although  subletting  from 
SOEs is, in most cases, illegal. 
 
54. 
The  Government  is  taking  proactive  measures  to  clarify  the  principles  of  land  law  and 
make them consistent for developing a property market in Viet Nam. For example, the new Land 
Law of 2003, supported under the SDPL, recognized the property market for the first time in Viet 
Nam and stipulates that land pricing should be based on real market transfer prices of land use 
rights under normal circumstances. The Land Law also augments and improves the framework 
for state management of land in terms of (i) land zoning and planning, (ii) transferring the power 
to  allocate  or  lease  land  and  issue  LURCs  from  the  Government  to  the  provincial  and  district 
People’s Committees, (iii) establishing the organization (nonprofit public service SOE) to create 
and manage land funds, (iv) establishing a uniform land registration system for undertaking all 
land registration in Viet Nam, (v) making clear the procedures for settling of land disputes, and 
(vi) clarifying the guiding principles for land pricing. 
 
55. 
One  of  the  key  achievements  of  the  new  Land  Law  is  making  land  use  rights 
transferable  with  market-based  pricing  mechanisms.  It  also  introduced  a  single  nationwide 
registry  system,  a  uniform  procedure  for  issuing  LURCs,  and  measures  to  improve  the  use  of 
idle land. A simplified and more transparent legislative framework will benefit SMEs by making 
the law easier to understand, particularly for owners or operators who have no legal background, 
and by generally reducing transaction costs.

B. 

Risks and Safeguards 

107.  There are four principal risks in implementing the SDPL-Subprogram II. The first involves 
ensuring effective coordination and cooperation within the government, both horizontally among 
different  ministries  and  agencies  concerned  and  vertically  with  the  provincial  and  district 
authorities. Consultation and coordination with the private sector and the aid community active 
in  SME  development  will  also  be  required.  It  is  expected  that  coordination  and  cooperation 
among  all  stakeholders  will  gradually  improve  with  the  increased  coordination  capacity  of 
ASMED, thus reducing the risk of overlap and inconsistencies in SME support activities. TA in 
support  of  SDPL  implementation  will  also  include  capacity  building  for  ASMED  to  reduce  this 
risk. 
 
108.  A  second  risk  pertains  to  good  governance  (particularly  as  related  to  effective  and 
transparent  implementation  of  the  existing  policies  and  laws)  in  the  central,  provincial,  and 
district  governments.  Governance  at  the  provincial  and  district  level  is  particularly  important, 
since the positive impact of the SDPL requires effective implementation of policies at the ground 
level. Also important is the need for the Government to allocate sufficient resources and staffs 
for  policy  implementation.  These  risks  are  common  to  several  programs  and  are  being 
addressed  through  the  implementation  of  the  comprehensive  Public  Administration  Reform 
Master Program (PARM) for 2001–2010, which is being supported by ADB.39
 
109.  A  third  risk  relates  to  the  technical  capacities  of  implementing  agencies.  Experience 
suggests  that,  given  adequate  technical  support,  the  Government’s  commitment  to  reforms  is 
strong.  In  implementing  previous  programs,  delays  were  caused  predominantly  by  the  lack  of 
technical expertise and of the consensus-building approach in enacting of laws and regulations. 
To reduce this risk, the TAs from ADB, AFD, and KfW have been formulated and implemented 
through  discussions  with  all  implementing  agencies  at  the  technical  level.  Many  requirements 
pertain to completing the legal framework and putting in place modern information technology-
based systems, taking into consideration the experience of other countries. The SDPL will also 
involve coordination with aid agencies in their respective areas in each component. As ADB has 
been serving as a co-chair of the donor coordination committee, this remains an important task.

Definition of Small- and Medium-Sized Enterprises (SMEs)  

Decree  90  defines  small-  and  medium-size  enterprises  (SMEs)  to  be  “those  business 
1. 
and  production  establishments  that  have  registered  under  the  current  legislation,  have  the 
registered capital of less than D10 billion at business registration agencies and/or the average 
number of annual permanent employees of less than 300.” Recognizing that this SME grouping 
is  too  general  to  provide  useful  data  for  policy  formulation,  the  Ministry  of  Planning  and 
Investment  (MPI)  introduced  a  further  size  segmentation  in  its  SME  Development  Plan  2006–
2010. This new segmentation further breaks out the SME category into microenterprises (fewer 
than 10 persons), small enterprises (10 to 49 persons) and medium-sized enterprises (50 to 299 
persons). While data on SMEs are not yet collected according to this segmentation, the formal 
adoption of the SME Development Plan will provide the needed mandate going forward.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
 
The  Government’s  10-year  Socio-Economic  Development  Strategy  (SEDS)  for  2001–2010  and  Socio-Economic 
Development  Plan  (2006–2010)  address  pro-poor  growth,  employment  generation,  and  poverty  reduction  through  a 
structural  shift  of  the  economy  from  agriculture  to  industry  and  services.  Since  the  early  1990s,  sustained  overall 
economic  growth  and  private-sector-led  employment  generation  have  actually  been  major  contributors  to  a  sharp 
decline in poverty in Viet Nam. The Viet Nam Household Living Standard Survey in 2004 showed that the poverty rate 
fell  from  58%  in  1993  to  19.5%  in  2004.  Improvements  in  the  social  conditions,  such  as  education  levels  and  infant 
mortality, have been reflected in an increase in the country’s ranking in the United Nations Development Programme’s 
human development index.2   
 
In turn, the poverty assessment by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in its country strategy and program (CSP) for 
2007–2010 endorses the contribution of economic growth to poverty reduction, with particular attention to the roles of 
small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and associated job creation in the industry and service sectors.3   
 
In  particular,  the  proposed  Subprogram  II  of  the  SME  Development  Program  Loan  (SDPL)  Cluster  will  support 
implementation  of  the  country’s  new  Enterprise  Law,  which  is  envisaged  to  ease  entry  barriers  to  start  up  formal 
businesses through reform in registration and licensing procedures. In the medium term, resulting competition among 
enterprises is expected to stimulate the economy’s overall productivity, raising the potential growth rate. The benefits 
of improved productivity will be multiplied by improved access to financial resources by enterprises, also addressed by 
the  SDPL,  further  enriching  the  growth  potentials.  In  Viet  Nam,  a  strong  positive  correlation  has  been  empirically 
observed  between  a  rise  in  per  capita  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  and  poverty  reduction  over  the  past  decade 
(based on Viet Nam Living Standards Surveys in 1993, 1998, and 2002)4 and, if this trend continues in the years to 
come, growth-oriented reforms supported by SDPL are likely to contribute positively to poverty reduction in an indirect 
manner. 
 
SDPL-supported reforms would also have critical importance to mitigate the temporary adverse impacts, if any, which 
may  result  from  Viet  Nam’s  accession  to  the  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO)  and  other  reforms  for  the  country’s 
transition  to  a  market  economy.  In  the  process  of  trade  liberalization  adjustment,  factors  of  production—including 
labor—would  have  to  shift  from  less  productive  sectors  to  more  productive  ones.  Through  streamlining  the  formal 
processes to start up new businesses, the SDPL  will facilitate this adjustment process  by creating new  employment 
opportunities in the emerging competitive sectors, and hence relieve its negative impacts on the poor.

 1. 
The Government of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam (the Government) is committed to poverty 
reduction as a primary objective of the country's development. To achieve the target for reducing incidence 
of  poverty  in  the  country,  there  must  be  rapid  economic  growth,  social  progress  and  equity,  and 
development  of  a  corruption-free  and  strong  state  apparatus.  Sector  strategies  for  achieving  these  goals 
have been delineated in the Socioeconomic Development Plan and the Comprehensive Poverty Reduction 
and Growth Strategy (CPRGS). 

2. 
 To sustain rapid economic growth, realize social progress and equity and develop a corruption-free 
and  strong  state  apparatus,  the  Government  recognizes  the  importance  of  establishing  an  enabling 
environment for the private sector, the small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in particular, which make up 
majority  of  the  private  sector.  CPRGS  targets  reduction  of  poverty  incidence  by  approximately  12 
percentage points between 2001 and 2010. Economic growth required for Viet Nam to realize such target 
will increasingly be dependent on the performance of the private/SME sector, perceived as the main engine 
for the next round of economic growth. 

3. 
Viet  Nam  has  made  series  of  efforts  in  support  of  the  private  sector.  The  Communist  Party 
Resolution  14/NQ-TW  (2002)  and  Prime  Minister's  Decision  94/2002/QD-TTg  (2002)  formally 
recognized the private sector as an important pillar for economic development and employment generation. 
To  support  the  SMEs,  the  Government  also  issued  Decree  90/2001/ND-CP  on  "Support  for 
Development of SMEs" in November 2001 and officially indicated for the first time its solid commitment 
to  support  SME  development  in  Viet  Nam.  Further,  with  the  promulgation  of  the  new  Enterprise  Law 
(NEL) in November 2005, the Government has laid the foundation for the continued reforms to promote 
the development of the SME sector. 

4. 
The  Government  recognizes  the  fact  the  SME  sector  still  faces  many  challenges  in  creating  an 
enabling  business  environment  in  Viet  Nam  due  in  part  to  its  incomplete  policy,  legal,  and  institutional 
frameworks  in  support  of  business  operations.  However,  the  Government's  commitment  to  meet  and 
overcome these challenges is strong in order to establish an environment conducive to the development of 
an efficient, market-oriented SME sector. The process for building such an environment is viewed by the 
Government as being indispensable for the country to achieve its target economic growth and prosperity that 
is free of poverty.

6. 
Although  the  original  Enterprise  Law  simplified  business  registration  by  reducing  time,  cost,  and

licenses and to apply standard approaches to limit the number of new licenses. While the business licensing 
reform  plan,  as  a  decree  under  the  NEL,  has  been  drafted,  the  Government  is  committed  to  further

overall spirit of the new NEL. 

 

Establishing Policy and Institutional Framework for SME Development

Effectively  of  the  new  NEL  in  July  2006  has  launched  the  new  phase  of  related  reforms.  These

requirements  and  procedures.  In  addition,  a  legal  framework  to  further  improve  the  registration  process, 
which will occur based on inter-ministerial coordination, will be issued as well.

direction, and effective coordination between the different stakeholders in policy delivery, both horizontally

functions. Support programs remain uncoordinated and often overlap, reducing their impact.
